Then, we have shown that statistical fits often used to extrapolate the long-term behavior of the epidemics are greatly affected by the magnitude of the last data point, despite values of
R 2
close to one, leading to unrealistic or overconfident estimates of confidence intervals on the forecast of the total number of infections.
45,46 In the early stage of the epidemics, we have shown that knowing the last data point with a relative 20% error can lead to a final extrapolation of infections with an error of several orders of magnitude. In order to improve the estimates of statistical models, one should replace
R 2
estimates by a formal comparison of model-alternatives using information criteria (e.g., AIC or BIC) or a log-likelihood approach with a leave-one-out cross-validation procedure.
